comments.content: when an interface is down and become up a level 3 message is created. So D is correct

discussion.content:
None of these are really right...
They are just normal log messages of Notification Level (lvl 5)

choices.D: The first log message is an error message with a severity level of 3.
choices.B: The first log message is categorized as a warning message.
choices.C: These messages regarding interface status are normal output and will always be displayed when you exit config mode.
choices.A: These two log messages will not have a severity level. They are not errors but are just informational messages.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the shown below.
%LINK-3-UPDOWN: Interface Serial0/0, changed state to up
%LINEPROTO-5-UPDOWN: Line protocol on Interface Serial0/0, changed state to up
What statement is correct regarding the output shown in the graphic?

choices.D: There is an HSRP group number mismatch
choices.A: There is an HSRP group track command misconfiguration
choices.E: This is not an HSRP issue; this is routing issue. A
choices.C: There is an HSRP authentication misconfiguration
choices.B: There is an HSRP group priority misconfiguration

questions.answer_description:
When looking at the HSRP configuration of R1, we see that tracking has been enabled, but that it is not tracking the link to R5, only the link to R2:

R1 should be tracking the Eth 0/1 link, not 0/0 to achieve the desired affect/

discussion.content: The correct choice is D as the filter is applied on the OSPF process, not on the interface.

choices.E: The ACL configured on R4 is blocking inbound traffic on the interface connected to R2 D
choices.B: This is an OSPF issue between R4 and R2
choices.C: This is a DHCP issue between R4 and R2
choices.A: HSRP issue between R4 and R2
choices.D: The distribute-list configured on R4 is blocking route entries

questions.answer_description: If we look at the configuration on R4 we see that there is a distribute list applied to OSPF, which blocks the 172.16.20.0/24 and 172.16.10.0/24 networks.

discussion.content: I agree with Batex. The answer is dhcp missconfiguration.

Absence of neighbour not necessary caused by OSPF issues. It may be interface of address issues. For example, lack of ip address due to dhcp misconfiguration. So we need check interfaces statuses and configurations on both routers.

questions.answer_description: If we issue the "show ip route" and "show ip ospf neighbor" commands on R5, we see that there are no learned OSPF routes and he has no OSPF neighbors.

choices.B: There is an OSPF issue between R5and R4
choices.C: There is a DHCP issue between R5 and R4
choices.A: HSRP issue between R5 and R4
choices.E: The ACL configured on R5 is blocking traffic for the subnets advertised from R4.
choices.D: The distribute-list configured on R5 is blocking route entries

discussion.content: C is the correct. They ask you what the problem is, not the solution.
B is correct. I make a LAB and I configured R1 to ospf network point-to-multipoint non-broadcast and it does not work. When I configure as neighbor point to each other it works!

questions.answer_description:
In order for two OSPF routers to become neighbors, they must have matching network types across the links. In this case, we see that R1 has been configured as non-broadcast and R3 is using point to point non-broadcast.


This can be seen by issuing the "show running-config" command on each router, or the "show ip ospf interface" command:

choices.D: The hello, dead and wait timers on R1 need to be reconfigured to match the values on R3.
choices.A: The serial interface in R1 should be taken out of the shutdown state.
choices.B: A neighbor statement needs to be configured in R1 and R3 pointing at each other.
choices.C: The R1 network type should be changed to point-to-multipoint non-broadcast.
